Dr. Smith.A7: GDPR consent is required for including subscriber personal data in telephone directories published by third-party providers, and such consent may be given to the operator or any directory provider.
Dr. Smith.A8: Article 12(2) Directive 2002/58, Article 2(f) Directive 2002/58, Article 95 GDPR, Article 4(11) GDPR, Article 6(1)(a) GDPR
Dr. Smith.A13: Article 4(11) of the GDPR defines the 'consent of the data subject' as requiring a 'freely given, specific, informed and unambiguous' indication of the data subject's wishes.
Dr. Smith.A15: It follows from a contextual and systematic interpretation of Article 12 of Directive 2002/58 that the consent under Article 12(2) relates to the purpose of the publication of personal data.
Dr. Smith.A17: Article 1(1) of Directive 2002/58 provides for the harmonisation of national provisions to ensure equivalent protection of fundamental rights.
Dr. Smith.A23: Such consent is necessary in order for the personal data relating to the subscriber to be included in directories.
Dr. Smith.A25: As the Court has already held, such prior information gives the subscriber opportunity to consent to publication.
Dr. Smith.A33: Confirms GDPR-standard consent is required for directory inclusion, strengthening subscriber control.

Prof. Chen.A7: Valid GDPR consent can be given to any directory provider, not just the original operator, for inclusion in telephone directories.
Prof. Chen.A8: Article 12(2) Directive 2002/58, Article 4(11) GDPR, Article 6(1)(a) GDPR
Prof. Chen.A13: Article 4(11) GDPR requires freely given, specific, informed and unambiguous indication of wishes.
Prof. Chen.A15: Contextual interpretation shows consent relates to purpose of publication, not provider identity.
Prof. Chen.A17: The directive aims to ensure equivalent protection of fundamental rights in electronic communications.
Prof. Chen.A23: Consent is necessary for subscriber data to be included in directories.
Prof. Chen.A25: Prior information enables consent to publication in public directories.
Prof. Chen.A33: Strengthens subscriber autonomy by clarifying that GDPR consent standards apply to directory inclusion.

Dr. Smith.A7: A subscriber's request to withdraw personal data from telephone directories constitutes exercise of the right to erasure under Article 17 GDPR.
Dr. Smith.A8: Article 17 GDPR, Article 12(2) Directive 2002/58, Article 6(1)(a) GDPR, Article 7(3) GDPR, Article 16 GDPR, Article 95 GDPR
Dr. Smith.A13: Under Article 12(2) of Directive 2002/58, subscribers must have opportunity to have personal data withdrawn from directories.
Dr. Smith.A15: The grant of such opportunity does not constitute a specific obligation excluding GDPR provisions.
Dr. Smith.A17: Directive 2002/58 does not contain indications as to modalities of withdrawal requests.
Dr. Smith.A23: Article 17(1)(b) and (d) provides the right to erasure without undue delay.
Dr. Smith.A33: Classifies withdrawal requests as Article 17 erasure rights, giving stronger legal protection.

Prof. Chen.A7: Withdrawal of consent to directory publication triggers Article 17 GDPR erasure rights.
Prof. Chen.A8: Article 17 GDPR, Article 7(3) GDPR, Article 95 GDPR
Prof. Chen.A13: Subscribers must have opportunity to withdraw personal data from directories.
Prof. Chen.A15: This opportunity does not exclude application of GDPR provisions.
Prof. Chen.A23: Article 17(1) grants right to obtain erasure without undue delay.
Prof. Chen.A33: Treats withdrawal as Article 17 erasure, providing stronger protection than mere rectification.

Dr. Smith.A7: A DPA may require directory providers to take measures to inform third-party controllers of subscriber consent withdrawal.
Dr. Smith.A8: Article 5(2) GDPR, Article 24 GDPR, Article 19 GDPR, Article 7(3) GDPR
Dr. Smith.A13: Article 24 GDPR requires controllers to implement appropriate technical and organisational measures.
Dr. Smith.A15: It follows from Article 5(2) and Article 24, read with Article 19, that controllers must inform other recipients.
Dr. Smith.A17: To ensure effectiveness of consent withdrawal rights under Article 7(3).
Dr. Smith.A23: Article 5(2) and Article 24 impose general accountability requirements.
Dr. Smith.A28: Such an approach would be contrary to Article 7(3) which provides it must be as easy to withdraw as to give consent.
Dr. Smith.A33: Imposes chain notification obligations on controllers to facilitate consent withdrawal.

Prof. Chen.A7: Directory providers must notify other controllers when subscribers withdraw consent under accountability principles.
Prof. Chen.A8: Article 5(2) GDPR, Article 19 GDPR, Article 24 GDPR
Prof. Chen.A13: Controllers must implement appropriate measures to ensure and demonstrate compliance.
Prof. Chen.A15: General obligations require controllers to inform recipients of consent withdrawal.
Prof. Chen.A17: Ensures effectiveness of withdrawal rights and maintains consent-purpose linkage.
Prof. Chen.A23: Articles 5(2) and 24 impose accountability and compliance requirements.
Prof. Chen.A28: Withdrawal must be as easy as giving consent per Article 7(3).
Prof. Chen.A31: Court shifts from textual reading of accountability to principle that withdrawal should be practically effective.
Prof. Chen.A33: Creates notification cascades ensuring practical effectiveness of consent withdrawal.

Dr. Smith.A7: A DPA may order directory providers to take reasonable steps to inform search engines of erasure requests.
Dr. Smith.A13: Article 17(2) requires taking reasonable steps to inform other controllers of erasure requests.
Dr. Smith.A17: The objective is to strengthen the right to be forgotten in the online environment.
Dr. Smith.A23: Under Article 17(2), controllers must take reasonable steps including technical measures.
Dr. Smith.A25: Search engine activities constitute processing of personal data within Article 4(2).
Dr. Smith.A33: Extends erasure notification obligations to include informing search engines.

Prof. Chen.A7: Directory controllers must take reasonable steps to notify search engines of subscriber erasure requests under Article 17(2).
Prof. Chen.A13: Article 17(2) obliges controllers who made data public to inform other controllers of erasure requests.
Prof. Chen.A15: The obligation specifically applies to information made available online by search engines.
Prof. Chen.A17: Recital 66 indicates the objective is to strengthen the right to be forgotten online.
Prof. Chen.A23: Controllers must take reasonable steps to inform search engines of erasure requests.
Prof. Chen.A25: Search engine indexing and display constitutes personal data processing.
Prof. Chen.A33: Strengthens online right to be forgotten by requiring search engine notification.
